p: Since its identification in North America in the 1970s, Lyme disease has become one of the most commonly reported vector-borne zoonoses in the temperate world [21], [22], [23]. Lyme disease is caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi [23]. B. burgdorferi is transmitted by ticks, which feed on wildlife reservoir hosts, such as rodents and birds. In humans, this bacterium causes a cutaneous phase marked by an acute febrile illness similar to influenza and is usually characterized by a bull's-eye rash [23], [24]. If left untreated, the bacteria can move to multiple organs leading to neurological and cardiac symptoms and then to late Lyme disease with further neurologic manifestations and Lyme arthritis [23], [24].
